awd_titl_txt: Dynamic Modeling and Identification of Human Metabolic Energy Expenditure with Applications to Prosthetic Gait
awd_abstract_narration:
Metabolic energy expenditure is a critical performance measure of human motion, and its implication has a broad range of scientific, clinical, and engineering applications.  In particular, assessing metabolic cost of prosthetic gait is important for diagnosis, design, and usability tests.  This award supports establishing a novel joint-based model that evaluates metabolic energy expenditure without the limitations inherent in common experimental measurements (time delays, limited task and range of motion due to equipment) or traditional muscle-based models (excessive number of unknown parameters, complex interactions between muscles and the surroundings, reliance on non-active human parameters).  Given the increasing demand and large number of people (more than 173,000 users in the U.S.) who would benefit from lower-limb prostheses, the model implementation into prosthetic design optimization will have broad social impacts by resolving the major hurdles to their wide-spread use through reduced metabolic cost and fatigue.  Also, the reduced development cost due to reduced usability tests will make products available to more economically diverse communities.  The collaborations between engineering and clinical disciplines will be mutually beneficial and enhance networks and partnerships for research and education, which will involve underrepresented (race, gender, disability) groups at various stages.  The calculation algorithm will be open-sourced for the prostheses developers in industry and academia. 
 
The goals of this project are to establish a joint-space dynamic model of metabolic energy expenditure by integrating the laws of thermodynamics and the principles of multibody system dynamics, and implement the model for energy-efficient prosthetic gait.  Specific objectives are to: (1) derive a general dynamic model of metabolic energy expenditure and identify and validate the joint-space model parameters from experiments; (2) introduce a modeling and identification framework of metabolic cost for locomotion of individuals with transtibial prostheses and experimentally validate; and (3) implement the models into a nonlinear programming algorithm to optimize the lower-limb prosthetic alignment for minimum metabolic cost of prosthetic gait, and experimentally demonstrate proof-of-concept.  The muscle energetic properties will be mapped to the joint space, and the energetic effects of negative work, intra/inter-joint coupling, and muscle co-contraction will be modeled.  The joint-space parameters estimated from active human subjects will provide the model with improved accuracy and efficient calculations, which can be used to evaluate metabolic cost for complex non-periodic functional tasks that may not be experimentally verifiable by traditional means.  The model also enables real-time calculations of instantaneous metabolic rate as a function of time.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit:  The research goal of this project was to establish a model of human metabolic energy expenditure (MEE) and extend it to prosthetic gait energetics.  The overarching research question was, given a motion and actuation of a human, how much metabolic energy is expended?  Unlike existing models for individual muscles that were obtained empirically, this research focused on rigorous mathematical approaches based on first principles such as the first law of thermodynamics and the work-energy principle.  This approach allowed the derivation of MEE in terms of joint-space state (position and velocity) and actuation variables, which can be directly used in conjunction with the conventional human motion prediction and analysis.  While the model forms were obtained theoretically, the model parameters were obtained and validated experimentally.  The experiments resulted in complete data acquired from able-bodied human subjects and prosthetic users and post-processed data including the indirect calorimetry as well as the typical kinematics and dynamics, all processed for time-synchronization of whole-body joints (including upper-body and bilateral).  Comparative analyses against the experiments showed the validity of the model across subjects and walking speeds with respect to accuracy and trends.  In particular, the model could systematically demonstrate the minimum cost of transport for walking with preferred speed, which has only been observed empirically in the existing studies.  From a completely different perspective through a supplemental fund, the MEE model was also obtained using a data-driven approach.  The regression-based model showed an acceptable level of consistency with the theory-driven model, and some discrepancies between the two provide further insights that are not available through each method alone.  In addition, the understandings obtained from this project were also extended to establish a proof-of-concept model of power consumption for permanent-magnet brushed DC servomotors.  The model was validated against experimental measurements and demonstrated true optimality of electrical power consumption, as compared with other proxy models used in the literature.

Broader impacts:  The research was integrated into comprehensive education and outreach plans in various aspects.  Three Ph.D. (including one female) and one master students were directly supported through this grant, which also enabled them to participate as mentors in two of NYU’s annual summer K-12 STEM programs (attended by a total of ten high school students and six teachers, including several minorities and females).  Numerous other master and undergraduate students have participated through MS projects and NYU’s annual summer undergraduate research program.  Disseminations included development of new modules for existing courses in robotics and dynamics and a new graduate-level course “Robotic Gait and Manipulation,” publications in journals and conference presentations, and participations in NYU’s annual research expos. 


Last Modified: 07/22/2022
Modified by: Joo H Kim
por.por_txt_cntn:
Intellectual merit:  The research goal of this project was to establish a model of human metabolic energy expenditure (MEE) and extend it to prosthetic gait energetics.  The overarching research question was, given a motion and actuation of a human, how much metabolic energy is expended?  Unlike existing models for individual muscles that were obtained empirically, this research focused on rigorous mathematical approaches based on first principles such as the first law of thermodynamics and the work-energy principle.  This approach allowed the derivation of MEE in terms of joint-space state (position and velocity) and actuation variables, which can be directly used in conjunction with the conventional human motion prediction and analysis.  While the model forms were obtained theoretically, the model parameters were obtained and validated experimentally.  The experiments resulted in complete data acquired from able-bodied human subjects and prosthetic users and post-processed data including the indirect calorimetry as well as the typical kinematics and dynamics, all processed for time-synchronization of whole-body joints (including upper-body and bilateral).  Comparative analyses against the experiments showed the validity of the model across subjects and walking speeds with respect to accuracy and trends.  In particular, the model could systematically demonstrate the minimum cost of transport for walking with preferred speed, which has only been observed empirically in the existing studies.  From a completely different perspective through a supplemental fund, the MEE model was also obtained using a data-driven approach.  The regression-based model showed an acceptable level of consistency with the theory-driven model, and some discrepancies between the two provide further insights that are not available through each method alone.  In addition, the understandings obtained from this project were also extended to establish a proof-of-concept model of power consumption for permanent-magnet brushed DC servomotors.  The model was validated against experimental measurements and demonstrated true optimality of electrical power consumption, as compared with other proxy models used in the literature.
Broader impacts:  The research was integrated into comprehensive education and outreach plans in various aspects.  Three Ph.D. (including one female) and one master students were directly supported through this grant, which also enabled them to participate as mentors in two of NYU’s annual summer K-12 STEM programs (attended by a total of ten high school students and six teachers, including several minorities and females).  Numerous other master and undergraduate students have participated through MS projects and NYU’s annual summer undergraduate research program.  Disseminations included development of new modules for existing courses in robotics and dynamics and a new graduate-level course "Robotic Gait and Manipulation," publications in journals and conference presentations, and participations in NYU’s annual research expos.
